title: A bipartisan argument for expanding Medicaid amid the coronavirus threat | Opinion
summary:
It is difficult to argue that the Tennesseans doing “essential work” for us should not have access to essential health care.
And the evidence indicates that populations with greater health care access have more favorable health outcomes.
Over the last several years, we have learned a great deal about the consequences of state decisions on Medicaid expansion.
Tennessee’s decision on Medicaid expansion, however, has been made by default — more by inaction than action.
For the good of our citizens, our economy, and our health care system, Tennessee should finally expand Medicaid.

title: Study: Nashville ranked 4th hottest real estate market in nation
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WKRN) – Yes, it’s a new year and yes, Nashville’s housing market is still on fire– with many real estate experts calling our market ‘hot.’It’s so hot, in fact, it was ranked as 4th hottest in the nation when it comes to home value growth.
The Zillow Home Price Expectations Survey[i], sponsored by Zillow and conducted quarterly by Pulsenomics LLC, asks more than 100 economists, investment strategists and real estate experts for their predictions about the U.S. housing market.
On average, panelists said they expected U.S. home values to grow by 2.8% in 2020.
Here’s what they found in the Nashville metro in 2020:· 59% of panelists expect home values to grow faster than their expected national rate (2.8%).
· 31% of panelists expect home values to grow slower than they do nationally· 10% of panelists expect home values to grow about the same as they do nationally.

title: Tennessee Comptroller keeping eye on Metro budget issues
summary:
State Comptroller Justin Wilson bluntly told members to get Metro’s financial house in order, or his office would take over Nashville’s city budget.
No one can remember such a public warning before Metro Council members from the state comptroller, whose office signs off on local budgets across the state.
“I hope it’s clear there are some serious financial concerns in Nashville,” said comptroller Wilson at the mid-November meeting.
Public schools, police, and emergency responders are among the many affected if their slice of the metro budget pie is cut.
In a quick letter back the state comptroller approved the new spending plan–conditionally.

title: Republicans Are Trying, Once Again, to Basically Ban Abortion in Tennessee
summary:
The governor declared that he and his Republican colleagues would be bringing comprehensive abortion restrictions this session, including a so-called “fetal heartbeat bill” to ban abortion care once a “heartbeat” has been detected.
The use of telemedicine is banned for medication abortions, and minors cannot receive abortion care without parental consent.
In 2014, Tennessee passed a constitutional amendment—Amendment One—which says nothing in the state constitution guarantees the right to an abortion.
According to the Guttmacher Institute, a reproductive rights-focused think tank, nine states ban abortion in cases where sex selection is a deciding factor.
Two states have bans on abortions for reasons of race, and two states ban abortion in cases of fetal genetic anomaly.

summary:
Within Tennessee, cities that posted the highest scores included Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga.
The ranking is based on various socioeconomic factorsThe next best-positioned city in Tennessee, Knoxville, ranked very highly in the same categories that were responsible for Nashville’s high score.
Chattanooga’s relatively high rank of 92 can be credited to slightly different socioeconomic factors in the city compared to Knoxville and Nashville.
Tennessee cities that still placed in the top half of U.S. cities when ranking them according to their predicted economic prosperity in the new decade included Memphis (113), Johnson City (150), and Clarksville (162).
Cities in the Volunteer State where the economic outlook appears bleak included Cleveland (207), Morristown (259), Jackson (296), and Kingsport (332).

title: 3.8 magnitude earthquake felt in East Tennessee
summary:
FINCASTLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — A 3.8 magnitude earthquake was felt in East Tennessee on Monday afternoon.
The United States Geological Survey said the earthquake was recorded near Fincastle in Campbell County at 1:12 p.m. CST.
The preliminary depth was measured at 35.4 kilometers, which is considered a shallow earthquake by USGA.
The earthquake was felt around East Tennessee and southern Kentucky.
For more information on Monday's earthquake, visit USGA's website.

title: 2019 homicide numbers drop in Nashville
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — According to an independent count of homicides kept by NewsChannel 5, the number of criminal homicides dropped in 2019, compared to the previous year.
The NewsChannel 5 count shows there were at least 76 cases of criminal homicide in 2019.
That would mark a drop from the year before -- Metro Police reported 88 deaths in 2018 and 107 deaths in 2017.
The final reported criminal homicide of 2019 came just minutes before midnight, when police say 18-year-old Marchellos Devens was found with several gunshot wounds inside a Nissan Altima stopped on the side of an exit ramp on I-65 South at Rosa Parks Blvd.
Devens was taken to the hospital but later died.

title: 2020 off to deadly start for Nashville pedestrians, drivers
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — Statistics show 2020 is off to a deadly start for both pedestrians and drivers in Nashville.
According to Walk Bike Nashville, 32 people were killed while walking in Nashville in 2019, making it the worst year on record.
“It’s absolutely getting worse,” said Lindsey Ganson, Director of Advocacy and Communications for Walk Bike Nashville.
She said while drivers need to stay alert and slow down, adding more crosswalks, making signals longer and increasing crossing times can make roads safer for cars and pedestrians.
Ganson said in a growing city, more pedestrians will be walking along roads, as well and drivers need to be prepared.

title: Tornadoes Kill 25 in Tennessee, Shredding Buildings in Nashville Area
summary:
DOUBLE SPRINGS, Tenn. — Jean Gregory had been fast asleep when her husband yanked her to the floor and flung himself on top of her for six, seven, maybe 10 minutes, as they waited for the tornado that had descended on their small community in Putnam County, Tenn., to finally pass.
“It just shook the house — they said it moved off the foundation,” said Mrs. Gregory, 73, as she surveyed the ruins of the house she had shared for decades with her husband.
Around them, it was much worse.
At least 19 people died on Tuesday morning in Putnam County after a series of tornadoes cut a swath across the central part of Tennessee, killing at least 25 people in all.
In Mrs. Gregory’s neighborhood, a mix of trailers, houses and modest apartments, the devastation was everywhere.

title: TDOT reports some slick spots on highways, especially bridges and overpasses
summary:
Tennessee Department of Transportation crews continue to monitor roadways across Middle Tennessee as snow continues to fall and a winter weather advisory has been extended through 9 a.m. Friday morning.
Drivers are reporting more slick areas, especially on bridges and overpasses.
As 8:45 a.m. Metro Nashville police were responding to reports of about a dozen injury and property-damage crashes across the city.
The concern for black ice — when water and moisture on the road encounters freezing conditions causing slick and undetectable spots, especially on bridges and overpasses — was echoed by weather experts.

summary:

Free dental services provided at the one-day clinic include cleanings, fillings, extractions, dental x-rays, and oral hygiene and nutritional counseling.
Many of Nashville’s most vulnerable citizens do not have good oral health care because they cannot access or afford it.

A Nissan pickup truck, which Steele is believed to have driven to the motel, was found in the parking lot and impounded.
The man shot to death late Wednesday night at the Fiddlers Inn on Music Valley Drive is identified as Joshua Ryan Steele, 27, of Joelton, who was shot less than an hour after his 10:25 p.m. check-in.

NWS said that tornado caused damage to the outfield wall at the Loretto Sports Complex.

The two lawmakers want to move Tennessee’s presidential primary to be the first in the nation.
(AP Photo/Kimberlee Kruesi)NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) — Tennessee would be the first state in the nation to hold a presidential primary, freeing it from having to compete for attention on Super Tuesday, under a new bill.

title: Tennessee inmate moved to death watch ahead of scheduled execution
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WKRN) — Inmate Nicholas Sutton was moved to death watch Tuesday morning shortly after midnight ahead of his scheduled execution Thursday.
Death watch is the three-day period before an execution when strict guidelines are implemented to maintain the security and control of the offender and to maintain safe and orderly operations of the prison, according to the Tennessee Department of Correction.
FILE – This photo provided by Tennessee Department of Correction shows Nicholas Sutton.
Tennessee death row inmate Nicholas Sutton has chosen to die by the electric chair, making him the fifth inmate in a little over a year to choose electrocution over the state’s preferred execution method of lethal injection.
Sutton, sentenced to death in 1985 for stabbing fellow inmate Carl Estep after a confrontation over a drug deal, is scheduled to be executed on Feb. 20.

The other two suspects - described as a black man and white woman - sat in the back seat.
The suspects next drove the victim to the Walmart on the 4000 block of Nolensville Pike, where the suspects in the back seat tried to make purchases, which were declined.

title: Medical marijuana bill passes through Tennessee Senate committee, conditions attached
summary:

Despite having widespread support for legalization, medical marijuana measures have struggled in the Tennessee legislature.
A bill hasn’t passed through a committee since 2018, when Rep. Jeremy Faison (R-Cosby) lead a summer study and sponsored a bill to legalize the plant for medical purposes.
Opponents of medical marijuana legalization pointed to its Schedule 1 classification.
A Vanderbilt poll in 2017 showed nearly 80% support for medical marijuana legalization of some kind among Tennesseans.

title: A bipartisan argument for expanding Medicaid amid the coronavirus threat | Opinion
summary:
It is difficult to argue that the Tennesseans doing “essential work” for us should not have access to essential health care.
And the evidence indicates that populations with greater health care access have more favorable health outcomes.
Over the last several years, we have learned a great deal about the consequences of state decisions on Medicaid expansion.
Tennessee’s decision on Medicaid expansion, however, has been made by default — more by inaction than action.
For the good of our citizens, our economy, and our health care system, Tennessee should finally expand Medicaid.

title: Nashville has record-breaking month in home sales
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — New numbers from the Greater Nashville Realtors show that October was a record-breaking month for home sales in Nashville, with home sales up more than 15% over last year.
The biggest increase came in single-family homes, which also saw an increase in sale price.
According to the Greater Nashville Realtors, median home prices increased by more than $20,000 from October of 2018 to October of 2019, and Condo prices increased nearly $14,000.
The average amount of days on the market increased from 29 days in 2018 to 32 days in 2019.
November is expected to be a successful month for the real estate business as well, with more than 3,000 pending sales at the end of October.

title: Vice President Pence urges Congress to pass new trade deal at Goodlettsville event
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — Vice President Mike Pence visited Nashville Monday to headline an event on trade.
Vice President Pence urged Congress to move forward with the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement - a controversial new trade deal that will impact the lives of Tennessee farmers.
Crowds gathering here for the arrival of Vice President Pence.
Vice President Pen’s objective seemed to be to sell this new US Mexico Canada Agreement, which would replace NAFTA.
After the event was over the media was not allowed to ask the Vice President any questions.

title: TobyMac cancels Canadian tour after son dies in Nashville
summary:
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE – OCTOBER 15: TobyMac performs at the 50th Annual GMA Dove Awards on October 15, 2019 in Nashville, Tennessee.
(Photo by Jason Kempin/Getty Images)NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Christian artist TobyMac’s oldest son died this week in Nashville.
According to multiple reports, authorities found Truett McKeehan unresponsive after responding to reports of a person in cardiac arrest around 10:50 a.m. Wednesday.
Representatives for TobyMac later confirmed to the USA-Today Network that the 21-year-old had died.
TobyMac was reportedly in Canada when his son passed and has canceled the rest of his Canadian tour.

title: Snow in October? Speculations of a white Halloween pop up after Weather.com forecast
summary:
CLOSEThose checking their weather app or Weather.com this morning may have noticed a big snowflake next to Thursday, Oct. 31, aka Halloween.
The National Weather Service did not comment on the projected weather a week away since it's too far out to have a full picture of what may be coming.
And by 10:30 a.m. today on both the app and Weather.com site, the snowflake symbol was replaced by a rain cloud.
Yet, Nashville's Halloween (so far) is predicted to have a low that's below-freezing —dipping to 31 degrees per Weather.com.
Here are some of the city's cold records, according to the National Weather Service website's calendar:Oct. 30, 1925: Nashville records its earliest measurable snowfall, at 1 inch.

title: Country Music Hall of Fame breaks attendance record in 2019
summary:
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE – OCTOBER 20: Inductee Jerry Bradley and Connie Bradley seen with his Hall of Fame plaque during the 2019 Country Music Hall of Fame Medallion Ceremony at Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on October 20, 2019 in Nashville, Tennessee.
(Photo by Jason Kempin/Getty Images for Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum)NASHVILLE, Tenn. — The Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum says nearly 1.3 million people visited the Nashville, Tennessee, museum last year, breaking an annual attendance record.
The building also houses the Country Music Hall of Fame rotunda where the names of country music’s founding musicians are listed on plaques.
In addition to its permanent exhibit, the museum featured temporary exhibits last year about outlaw country music, Kacey Musgraves, Brooks & Dunn and Keith Whitley.

title: DMV: Prepare for long waits to get REAL ID before October 2020
summary:
You can tell if you have a REAL ID by looking for a gold star on your drivers license.
You'll need to get a REAL ID if you use your Drivers License as your identification to fly.
You do not need a REAL ID just to drive, and you do not need a REAL ID to vote.
You have to apply for your first REAL ID in person, even those who years ago already showed the exact same documents that REAL ID now requires.
You will have to get a new picture taken for REAL ID, with a smile the state hopes won't be a forced one.

title: Greta Van Fleet postpones sold out Nashville concert
summary:
CLOSEGrammy Award-winning rock upstart Greta Van Fleet postponed Sunday night's scheduled appearance in Nashville.
Slated to perform a sold out show at Municipal Auditorium, the band cited "persisting illness" as reason for postponing the tour stop.
The Michigan blues rock outfit rescheduled the show for Dec. 16.
"With wholehearted disappointment, we must share that we are unable to join the beautiful people of Nashville tonight due to persisting illness," the statement said.
It's the second postponement this weekend for Greta Van Fleet, following a New Orleans tour stop also rescheduled for December.

Daylight saving time is lurkingAdjust your clocks back one hour at 2 a.m. Nov. 3.
Otherwise you'll wake up early as daylight saving time in Tennessee ends on Sunday.
President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Uniform Time Act in 1966, which established daylight saving time from the second Sunday of March through the first Sunday of November.

title: Tennessee unemployment rate remains low in November
summary:
NASVHILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — New unemployment numbers for Tennessee show low unemployment numbers continuing to remain steady.
The overall seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the state is at 3.3%, lower than the national average of 3.5%.
While the national unemployment rate dropped in November, Tennessee's remained steady overall.
Of the 10 Metropolitian Statistical Areas (MSA) tracked in Tennesseee, the Clarksville area has the second-highest unemployment rate in the state at 3.7%, just behind the Memphis region.
Overall, there are 91 counties in Tennessee with unemployment under 5%, and only four counties with rates higher that 5%.

title: Nashville has record-breaking month in home sales
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — New numbers from the Greater Nashville Realtors show that October was a record-breaking month for home sales in Nashville, with home sales up more than 15% over last year.
The biggest increase came in single-family homes, which also saw an increase in sale price.
According to the Greater Nashville Realtors, median home prices increased by more than $20,000 from October of 2018 to October of 2019, and Condo prices increased nearly $14,000.
The average amount of days on the market increased from 29 days in 2018 to 32 days in 2019.
November is expected to be a successful month for the real estate business as well, with more than 3,000 pending sales at the end of October.

title: Storm clouds will block Middle Tennessee's view of meteor shower
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF/CNN) — A meteor shower is predicted to light up the sky Thursday night until Friday morning.
Rain is expected to move into the area around 10 p.m., but clouds will fill the sky before the rain hits, blocking the view.
The meteor shower is known as the alpha Monocertoid, which gets its name from the Monoceros constellation that lies southwest of the constellation Orion.
The meteor shower comes from the dust trail of an unknown comet, the meteor scientists said.
The conditions are lining up the way they did in 1995, so the meteor scientists are hopeful, but remind everyone that this is only a prediction.

title: Man killed in North Nashville shooting
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — A man has died at the hospital after a shooting Monday afternoon in North Nashville.
The shooting happened in the 1600 block of 25th Ave. North just before 3:30 p.m.Police say 20-year-old Aquan Avant was shot in the stomach.
He was rushed to Vanderbilt University Medical Center, where he later died.
Witnesses told police Avant and three acquaintances were standing outside a home when the gunman approached them on foot and opened fire.
The suspect, who ran away after the shooting, was described as a young man with short hair.

title: Doobie Brothers unite with Michael McDonald for tour
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) — Rock & Roll Hall of Fame nominees The Doobie Brothers are joining with singer and songwriter Michael McDonald for a 50th anniversary tour next year.
McDonald, who sang with the band starting in 1975 before starting his own solo career, surprised fans at The Doobie Brothers concert with a performance of "Takin' it to the Streets" on Monday in Nashville, Tennessee, at the Ryman Auditorium.
They had hits with "Listen to the Music," "Long Train Runnin'" and "China Grove."
They earned two Grammys with McDonald for "What a Fool Believes" and "Minute By Minute."
The tour will begin June 9 in West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Winter in Nashville can bring extremes
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WKRN) – Winter is coming.
A review of records kept by the National Weather Service office in Nashville tells the wintry tale.
The lowest temperature on record in Nashville is minus 17 degrees Fahrenheit, occurring on January 21st, 1985.
The Music City was basically spared from the 1993 winter “Storm of the Century,” with 2.8 inches of snow recorded.
The News 2 StormTracker team is taking a closer look at new plans and upgraded tools for winter weather preparedness.

title: Mayor Cooper announces cold weather sheltering plan for homeless community
summary:
Mayor Cooper released the Metro Cold Weather Overflow Sheltering Plan Thursday as a cold front moved into the region, which is expected to bring temps into the 30s and possibly create a wintry mix by next week.
"I had like two friends of mine had die out here from the cold weather,' said Nippers.
The overflow shelter site was also chosen based on an analysis of cold weather shelter capacity at primary community partner facilities and historical utilization rates of cold weather shelter space by Nashville’s homeless population.
Record single-night utilization lows were 760 (2018-2019), 903 (2017-2018), and 1,053 (2016-2017), indicating a downward trend in overall cold weather shelter utilization over the past three cold weather seasons.
Metro Social Services recorded all shelter attendance numbers when Metro’s overflow cold weather shelter was activated and in use.

title: NIH clinical trial of hydroxychloroquine, a potential therapy for COVID-19, begins
summary:
NIH clinical trial of hydroxychloroquine, a potential therapy for COVID-19, beginsNIAIDA clinical trial to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of hydroxychloroquine for the treatment of adults hospitalized with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has begun, with the first participants now enrolled in Tennessee.
The blinded, placebo-controlled randomized clinical trial aims to enroll more than 500 adults who are currently hospitalized with COVID-19 or in an emergency department with anticipated hospitalization.
NIH also recently launched a trial to study Remdesivir as a possible treatment for COVID-19.
That clinical trial is sponsored by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) [NCT04280705].

summary:

The event will feature live performances from local musicians/bands David Olney, Amy Black, Logan Ledger, King Corduroy, and Blackfoot Gypsie.

title: 2019 is the third-wettest year on record for Nashville
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — After a soggy weekend, the forecast for New Year’s Eve is shaping out to be much drier.
2019 will go down as the third-wettest year on record for Nashville.
The Music City saw 2.53'' of rain yesterday shattering the old record 2.18'' for December 29th.
Meanwhile, this is the 7th wettest year on record for Crossville with 67.96'' with 2018 holding the top spot with 74.88''.
Fortunately, we'll get several days to dry out with activities for the Music City Bowl on Monday and Music City Midnight celebrations for the New Year.

title: AAA expects record-breaking number of holiday travelers for end of the year
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — If you plan to travel over Christmas, Hannukah or New Years, you will have a lot of company.
AAA expects the number of travelers this year to be the highest ever since it began recording holiday travel numbers in 2000.
Staff are concerned about the threat of road rage, which tends to increase during hectic holiday travel.
"The more people that you put on any given road you're adding congestion that can lead to some tricky situations and some road rage scenarios," Megan Cooper with AAA Tennessee said.
For air travel, Dec. 22 is expected to be the busiest day at U.S. airports.

title: Hendersonville police officer Spencer Bristol hit, killed while chasing suspect
summary:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — A Hendersonville Police officer died Monday after being hit by a vehicle on Interstate 65 South.
Officer Spencer Bristol, 31, was pursuing a suspect into Davidson County on outstanding warrants.
The suspect vehicle crashed into another vehicle on Vietnam Vets, prompting two suspects inside to bail from the car.
A second suspect, 19-year-old Emani Martin, was not caught, prompting Officer Bristol to chase after him, but was hit by a vehicle as he crossed I-65 South.

title: Flu activity hits high activity level in Tennessee
summary:
Flu season began early and is hitting Tennessee hard this year.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, flu activity is now at its highest level across the state.
“Around the first, second week in December, in Middle Tennessee, that’s when we typically see it start to ramp-up,” said Brian Todd, Spokesperson for the Metro Public Health Department.
“During flu season, that can change rapidly, that doesn’t mean we won’t have a bad case of flu here,” said Todd.
“Want to make sure you’re getting your flu shot, but you also want to make sure you’re stopping the spread of germs.

title: Nashville Rally Planned for Dec. 17 in Support of Impeachment and Removal of President Trump
summary:
NASHVILLE, TN — Middle Tennesseans will rally at the Kefauver Federal Building in downtown Nashville on Tuesday, December 17th at 4:30 p.m. in support of the impeachment and removal of President Donald Trump.
This demonstration is part of a nationwide rapid response network of thousands of American citizens who have committed to public demonstrations on the eve of the vote on impeachment in the U.S. House of Representatives.
More than 100,000 people have signed up to rally in over 500 locations across the country to make it clear that even the President of the United States is NOT above the law.
https://www.trumpisnotabovethelaw.org/event/impeach-and-remove/search/ The rally in Nashville is organized by Nashville and Middle TN Indivisible, a grassroots organization dedicated to defending democracy, civil rights, dignity, and healthcare for all Tennesseans.

The fate of scooters in Nashville now hangs in the balance longer than expected.

“They can put out enough scooters that we don’t need 20 companies.”“I’m optimistic that with a renewed focus that there might be, we might see that one or two high-quality operators come in, we only have 1,000 scooters,” said O’Connell.

title: Will snow be a factor for Nashville's Tuesday afternoon and evening commute?
summary:
CLOSESnow may arrive in Middle Tennessee in time for Tuesday's afternoon and evening rush hour, but how much accumulation to expect on roads is uncertain.
WeatherTemperatures are expected to hit the freezing mark in Nashville around mid to late afternoon Tuesday, according to the NWS.
The Nashville school district will notify families of weather related delays or closures with a telephone call to the primary phone number listed with their student’s school.
Areas north of Interstate 40 and east of Interstate 65 are where the highest amounts of snow are expected.
Heavy coats and gloves will be the dress code Wednesday morning with temperatures expected be in the low 20s.

title: Brett Eldredge Is Getting In The Holiday Spirit With 2019 'Glow Live Tour'
summary:
Brett Eldredge will hit the road for a 10-date holiday tour in December.
The "Glow Live Tour" will kick off on December 4 with a show at Nashville's Ryman Auditorium, followed by stops in Chicago, Boston, Columbus and more.
"Since I was a kid, I've had the Christmas music spirit running heavily through my veins," Eldredge says.
Now taking my own Christmas tour out on the road at this huge level is a dream.
In addition to the new tour, Eldredge is also in the process of writing and recording new music for his upcoming album.
